The Co3O4 modified with 1 wt.% Cs was deposited on α-Al2O3 open-cell foam covered with different washcoats (MgO, MnO2, SiO2, TiO2), investigated by XRD, Raman microspectroscopy, nitrogen physisorption, XPS, SEM and TPR-H2 in order to elucidate interactions between Cs-Co3O4 and the washcoat and their effect on surface area, reducibility, dispersion, and low temperature decomposition of N2O. The samples with SiO2 and TiO2 washcoats had the largest surface areas. Only SiO2 did not interact with the active phase and did not change the reducibility of the catalyst. Although the same Cs concentration was adjusted during preparation of all catalysts, differences in the Cs/Co surface molar ratio were observed due to a different level of Co3O4 particles aggregation and cesium dispersion. Catalytic activity correlated with the surface Cs/Co molar ratio closely interconnected with the surface Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio while there were no direct relationships to the redox properties and surface area. The highest activity was achieved for the MgO washcoat prepared from carbonate with the highest Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio corresponding to the optimal Cs/Co surface molar ratio around 0.1. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cobalt oxide Cesium promoter Ceramic foam Supported catalyst N2O decomposition Washcoat Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Co3O4 mixed oxide is known as an effective catalyst for several redox reactions [1–5] due to the presence of cobalt in mixed valence states and the energetically feasible transition between them. The decomposition of N2O suitable for the elimination of N2O from industrial exhaust gasses is one of these reactions [5–13]. Alkali metals, especially potassium or cesium, act as an electron promoter of Co3O4 and considerably increase its catalytic activity for the decomposition of N2O [6,11,14–19]. The optimal amount of Cs that ensures high activity was found to be 1–2 wt.% [20] or 0.5–3 Cs atoms/nm2 [21–23]. However, for the industrial application of Cs/Co3O4 catalysts, several problems have been identified. Shaping even simple tablets is not easy, leading to insufficient mechanical strength, and preparation of more sophisticated shapes with larger external surface area, such as Rashing rings or quadralobes, was quite impossible. Other disadvantage of tablets is that the significant part of cobalt inside the tablet of common dimension (3–5 mm) is unused due to internal diffusion limitation and the catalytic reaction takes place only in the outer shell [24]. Moreover, cobalt is also toxic and quite expensive, especially now when the demand for efficient Li-ion batteries is growing rapidly. These problems can be solved by deposition of the cobalt active phase on a suitable carrier. SiO2 support materials with a range of micro/mesostructures to immobilize the Co3O4 catalyst were studied in [25] and highly dispersed Co3O4 nanoparticles were prepared by a sol-gel technique coupled with a rapid thermal process [26]. When Co3O4 was deposited on MnxOy and MgO [27], MgO with a high cobalt content (15 wt.%) was the most active for N2O decomposition. Co3O4 deposited on the MgO-based support also ensured the best catalytic performance of deN2O process in [28]. Regarding the Al2O3 support for Co3O4 catalysts, Grzybek et al. [29] confirmed the advantageous performance of α-Al2O3 in comparison to γ-/amorphous Al2O3. Supported cobalt mixed oxide deN2O catalysts have been studied in the form of monoliths [30,31], sieves [15,32], and tablets [13]. Currently, open-cell foams are highly promising. They consist of interconnected solid struts forming a network with relative high porosity, simultaneously high mechanical strength and a high interface area which results in lower pressure drop compared to a packed bed. Because of their geometrical structure, high performance in terms of gas/solid mass transport is guaranteed. In comparison to shaped bulk catalysts, a lower amount of active phase is necessary, which is additionally more effectively used as a result of the dispersion on the support. Foam-based catalysts for N2O decomposition have been studied only by Ho et al. (Rh/MgAl HT-derived film deposited on FeCr alloys foam) [33] and by our group (cobalt mixed oxide without/with Cs promoter on different foams) [4,34]. A comparison of wet impregnation and suspension methods of Co3O4 deposition on SiC foam showed that the suspension method led to the formation of two types of cuboctahedral shapes of Co3O4 nanocrystals with dominated (111) and (100) facets leading to higher N2O conversion [34]. Furthermore, a suitable foam material (Al2O3+SiO2, ZrO2, SiO2+Al2O3+C-graphite) for deposition of Cs/Co3O4 by impregnation was studied [4]. The support affected amount of deposited Co3O4 active phase as well as the Cs dispersion. From this point of view, the Al2O3+SiO2 foam was selected as the most appropriate support, but its disadvantage was quite low specific surface area (0.7 m2 g−1). To increase the surface of structured catalysts, the deposition of thin layer of porous material, so called washcoat, is widely used. A suitable washcoat can also improve active phase adhesion and catalytic properties. Al2O3 is the most common washcoat material because of its high surface area and high temperature resistance [35]. Other washcoat materials are different oxides, e.g. ceria or zirconia for CO oxidation over Co [36], titania for CO oxidation over dispersed Au or Pt and V2O5-WO3 for SCR NOx [37–39] or silica for H2O2 synthesis over Pd [40]. All these washcoats were applied only on monolith supports. Although (i) Co3O4 is the active catalyst for many reactions, (ii) open-cell foams have been widely studied during the last decade, and (iii) the washcoat technique is commercially used for monoliths, very little is known about open ceramic foams with washcoat and containing cobalt oxides [41,42]. The effect of the washcoat on Cs-Co3O4 deposited on the foam support has not been published yet. Similarly, the open-cell foams with washcoat as catalysts for N2O decomposition have not been described yet. The present work is part of our ongoing research of alkali-promoted cobalt-based catalysts deposited on open-cell ceramic foam support for the N2O decomposition. The paper presents the first fundamental work on (i) the possibility of increasing the surface area of the ceramic foam support by washcoating followed by cobalt spinel deposition and (ii) the assessment of the chemical and structural suitability of the washcoat for the N2O decomposition. The Al2O3+SiO2 open-cell foam was selected according to our previous investigation (the best support from [4]). Common washcoats (TiO2, SiO2 as well as MgO and MnO2), which are not typical washcoats for structured catalysts, but could exhibit a positive effect on catalytic activity in combination with Co3O4, were selected. Co3O4 with a constant content of Cs promoter was used as the active phase in all cases. The prepared catalysts were characterized and tested for the N2O decomposition. For comparison, an open cell foam with Co3O4-Cs deposited without any washcoat [4] was used. The work shows that the washcoat can influence not only the surface area but subsequently the catalytic activity by influencing the dispersion of active phase (Co3O4 and Cs entities) and by chemical interactions with the active phase. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization α-Al2O3 based ceramic foam (chemical composition: 85.0 wt.% Al2O3, 14.0 wt.% SiO2, 1.0 wt.% MgO, 10 ppi foam cell size, S BET = 0.7 m2∙g−1 [4], Lanik Ltd.) in the form of a cylinder with a size of 48 mm x 20 mm ( ± 2 mm) was used as a support. Washcoat deposition procedure Two methods were used for washcoat deposition: (i) suspension dip coating for the deposition of MgO from carbonate precursor, TiO2 and SiO2, and (ii) wet impregnation for the deposition of MgO from nitrate precursor and MnO2. The foams were cleaned with ethanol and dried at 105 °C for 1 h prior to the deposition of the washcoat. The deposition procedures of individual washcoats were as follows. (a) MgO washcoat from carbonate precursor: MgCO3 was prepared by co-precipitation of aqueous solution of magnesium nitrate and potassium carbonate. The precipitate was washed with water three times to remove residual K +. 8 g of MgCO3 was milled with 16 g of water and 160 g of 3 mm ZrO2 balls (Planetary Ball Mill PM 100, Retsch). Suspension was prepared by adding 150 ml of water to the milled phase. Dip coating was carried out at the fixed movement rate of 0.5 mm/s; the foam was submerged for 1 min. After each dipping, the foam was dried for 1 min and rotated for the next dipping. The foam was dipped in the solution four times and finally dried for 15 min under ambient conditions and for 20 h at 60 °C. The sample was calcined for 4 h at 500 °C. (b) TiO2 washcoat: 148.3 ml of cyclohexane, 63.4 ml of Triton X-114 non-ionic surfactant and 2.2 ml of distilled water were mixed. After stirring with magnetic stirrer for 15 min, 37 ml of titanium isopropanol was added. The solution was stirred for another 20 mins and then left to stand for 30 min. Dip coating conditions: immersion rate 60 mm min−1, immersed in solution for 30 s, rate of emergence 150 mm min−1. The foam was dried for 4 h under ambient conditions and calcined for 2 h at 500 °C. The preparation method was performed according to [43]. (c) SiO2 washcoat: 75 ml of ethanol were mixed with 50 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate. After stirring with magnetic stirrer for 10 mins, 12.5 ml of distilled water and 2.5 ml of concentrated HNO3 were added. After 60 min of stirring, the dip coating started - immersion rate 60 mm min−1, immersed in solution for 30 s, rate of emergence 150 mm min−1. The foam was dried for 4 h under ambient conditions and calcined for 2 h at 500 °C. The preparation method was performed according to [44]. (d) MgO washcoat from the nitrate precursor: A solution was prepared by dissolving 46 g of Mg(NO3)2 4H2O in 50 ml of distilled water at 60 °C. The foam was immersed in the solution for 20 min. The sample was then dried for 3 h at 115 °C and calcined for 4 h at 500 °C. (e) MnO2 washcoat: A solution was prepared by dissolving 50 g of Mn(NO3)2 4H2O in 50 ml of distilled water at 60 °C. The foam was immersed in the solution for 20 min. The sample was dried for 3 h at 115 °C and calcined for 4 h at 500 °C. Deposition of Co3 O4-Cs active phase The active phase of Co3O4-Cs was deposited on the foams with or without the washcoat by the wet impregnation method. The composition of the impregnation solution was 89.6 g of Co(NO3)2 . 6 H2O + 0.4 g of CsNO3 + 50 ml of H2O. The concentration of CsNO3 was adjusted to obtain 1 wt.% Cs in the active phase in all cases. The foams were submerged in the solution for 20 min and subsequently dried for 3 h at 105 °C and calcined for 4 h at 500 °C. For comparison, the reference sample Co-Cs/Al2O3, i.e. the sample without any washcoat, is also presented. The characterization and catalytic activity of this sample has been already published in [4] where this catalyst was marked as Co-Cs/Al-Si.The catalyst labeling is summarized in Table 1 . The catalysts were characterized by atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen physisorption, temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (TPR-H2), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Raman microspectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The details are given in the Supplementary. 2.2 Catalytic measurements The catalytic decomposition of N2O was performed in an integral fixed-bed stainless steel reactor (i. d. of 50 mm) in the temperature range of 300 to 450 °C and at ambient pressure. The inlet stream consisted of 0.1 mol.% N2O in N2 and GHSV = 1500 m3 m3 bed −1 h−1 was kept constant by variation of the total flow 679–987 ml min−1 (293 K, 101 325 Pa) according to different sample volumes. The catalysts were activated at 450 °C 1 h in inert gas, then N2O catalytic decomposition at 450 °C was measured for 10 h. After this period, where stable performance was checked, the temperature dependence of conversion measurement was launched with cooling rate of 5 °C min−1 and 2 h stay at each temperature (450–300 °C). N2O conversion was calculated from data achieved at steady state. Absence of external diffusion limitation within the range of applied flow rates was confirmed in separate tests. The IR analyzer (Sick) was used for the N2O analysis, since it is known that over non-noble metal oxides the only reaction products are nitrogen and oxygen [5]. 3 Results 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalysts The chemical compositions, i.e. contents of the deposited active phase and the washcoats, are presented in Table 2 . The amount of the deposited washcoats was altered from 1 to 4.6 wt.% according to their various chemical composition, structural properties, and preparation methods. The quantity of active phase deposited varied from 5.1 to 7.8 wt.% due to the different chemical and structural properties of the washcoat that affect the binding of the Co-Cs precursor to the washcoat surface [45]. The highest weight increment of the active phase was obtained on the MgO washcoated foams, while the lowest on the catalysts with SiO2 and TiO2 washcoats probably due to the lower adhesion of the nitrate precursor to the washcoat and the worse wettability of these materials. A similar phenomenon regarding TiO2 support has already been discussed in [28] . Theoretical washcoat thickness h, calculated at the assumption that the entire foam surface (S BET) is totally covered (using bulk density of the MgO 3.58 g cm−3, MnO2 5.03 g cm−3, TiO2 4.23 g cm−3 and 2.65 SiO2 g cm−3), shows that the amount of washcoat was sufficient to form a continuous layer of nanometer size. In case the foam is predominantly covered only on the geometric surface (not known) and the porosity of spinel phase is supposed, the theoretical washcoat thickness can be even much higher. Low-temperature nitrogen adsorption measurements showed an increase in the specific surface area of all catalysts compared to the reference sample without the washcoat (Table 2). The highest surface area was found for the catalysts with SiO2 and TiO2 washcoats; the surface area was three times and twice greater, respectively. Since these samples had the smallest weight of the deposited active phase but had noticeably higher surface area compared to other catalysts, the SiO2 and TiO2 washcoats themselves must have higher surface areas than other washcoats. The increase in the specific surface area is due to the deposited washcoat, but contribution to the specific surface area is also due to Co3O4-Cs since S BET of pure foam is of 0.7 m2 · g−1. The XRD results of the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 2. Intensive diffraction lines of phases from foam (corundum, mullite, and cordierite) were found out. Pyrolusite was identified in the catalyst coated with MnO2. Other washcoat phases were not detected due to their low content and/or amorphous structure. The formation of Co3O4 mixed oxide with spinel structure (ICDD, PDF-2 #00-043-1003) was confirmed by the presence of characteristic lines in the XRD patterns for all catalysts, albeit with low intensities. Spinel cell parameters a for the catalysts with washcoats exhibited slight differences compared to the reference sample, suggesting possible incorporation of cations from the washcoat to spinel lattice. The observed changes roughly correspond to the cationic radius, a decrease was found in the presence of SiO2 washcoats, while an increase was observed for other (Si4+ 0.40 Å, Co2+ 0.70 Å, Co3+ 0.60 Å, Mg2+ 0.72 Å, Mn2+ 0.83 Å, Ti4+ 0.67 Å [46]). However, it should be said that all values are still in the range of values published earlier in the literature for Co3O4 [47]. The crystallization of the spinel phase during calcination was hindered by the contact with the washcoat, which manifested itself in the formation of smaller crystallites in all cases. According to [48], the size and volume of the support pores significantly influence the crystallite size of cobalt oxide - larger crystallites are obtained for supports with larger pores, which is consistent with our result, where the reference sample has significantly larger pore volume than the washcoated samples (Fig. S1). The chemical composition of the surface was examined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to verify whether the washcoat and active phase layer covered the entire foam surface and what kind of species are located on the surface. To evaluate the quality of the washcoating, XPS Al 2p spectra measured for foam pieces were used, since aluminum was part of the foam support but not part of any washcoat and active phase layer. The intensity of the main peak at 74.6 eV informs on the content of Al observed by XPS (Fig. 2 ). The TiO2 and MgO-c layers completely cover the foam with such a thickness that Al is not observed. Washcoating with MnO2 and SiO2 is not so effective. Furthermore, MgO-n does not wholly cover the support and the intensity of the corresponding Al 2p peak is similar in this case to that of the reference sample without any washcoat. Regarding the chemical composition of the active phase, the powdered samples were used for XPS measurement (Fig. 3, Table 3). XPS Co 2p spectra (Fig. 3 ) showed more complex features in which peaks observed are attributed to Co2+ and Co3+ species in the Co3O4 spinel. The deconvolution of the Co 2p3/2 signal reveals three main components (at 779.1 ± 0.1 eV corresponding to Co3+, as well as at 780.6 ± 0.1 eV and 782.1 ± 0.1 eV – both attributed to Co2+). In the 3d XPS Cs spectra, two components 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 are identified at very similar positions of 724.8 ± 0.1 eV and 738.7 ± 0.1 eV, respectively. Value of 3d5/2 binding energy (BE) corresponds to BE of ionically bonded cesium CsOH (724.15 eV) [49] while presence of atomic Cs can be excluded (3d5/2 = 726.3–726 eV for Cs0) [50]. The oxidation state of Co in washcoated catalysts is influenced by the molar ratio of Cs/Co (Fig. 4 ). There are also shown results presented in our previous paper [4]. Combining both data, it can be seen that the dependence is non-monotonous and demonstrates a clear maximum of Co3+ abundance for Cs/Co about 0.1. For higher surface Cs/Co molar ratio, higher abundance of Co2+ on the surface was observed, similarly to the effect of K in K/Co-Mn-Al mixed oxides [51]. The non-monotonous dependence of Co3+/Co2+ on Cs/Co molar ratio is connected with the Cs ability to modify electron surface properties due to its low ionization potential [21]. Cesium (and alkali cations generally) is Lewis acid and has no electron donation effects. However, Cs increases the electron density and also basicity of oxygen anions in its coordination sphere under formation of anionradical O2- [52], which is in turn reflected in the decrease of the cobalt electron density due to the formation of the dipoles [38,45,52,53] and higher Co3+ presence on the surface. After passing the Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio maximum connected with Cs/Co of 0.1, the cesium ions come closer and mutual depolarization takes place connected with decrease in Co3+ content at the expense of Co2+. The morphology of catalysts was checked by scanning electron microscopy. Large clusters, discontinuous layer and aggregates of 200–400 nm as well as randomly dispersed tiny particles of Co-agglomerates were observed on the surface of all catalysts (Figs. S2, S3) and in the pores similarly to the reference sample [4]. The nonhomogeneous distribution of the cobalt oxide active phase was confirmed for all samples. However, EDS maps showed good cesium distribution on the surfaces of all catalysts. This means that some cesium atoms can be dispersed on the support/washcoat, and some are placed in the vicinity of the cobalt oxide particles or on its aggregates, thus causing differences in the local Co/Cs molar ratio on the catalyst surface. Evaluation of the morphology and arrangement of the washcoats was more difficult since the washcoats containing MnO2 and MgO prepared from nitrate solution were not clearly distinguishable on the surface; however, a nonhomogeneous distribution of Mg and Mn can be observed from the EDS maps (Fig. S2). The TiO2 washcoat covered the entire foam surface quite uniformly, while the characteristics of the SiO2 washcoat could not be determined due to the presence of SiO2 in the support foam material. The washcoat consisting of MgO from the carbonate precursor formed a cracked layer with a maximum thickness of 30 μm (Fig. S4) in accordance with the results obtained by using the suspension method in ref. [34] and contained a high amount of cobalt oxide particles within the washcoat, which can be observed by the intensity of white color. Therefore, it should be assumed that the discussed observations coincide roughly with those taken from XPS Al 2p spectra (Fig. 2 ). Raman spectra (Fig. 5 ; Table 4 ) confirmed the presence of Co3O4 spinel: the A1g mode belongs to the octahedral sites in O7h symmetry, and the F2g and Eg modes belong to the vibration of the tetrahedral and octahedral sites [53]. The positions of all bands in the both catalyst with Mg-containing washcoats were obviously shifted to lower values in comparison to those of the reference sample, indicating structural changes in the spinel. The shift towards lower wavenumbers (red shift) is related to the presence of impurities, the shortening of the bond length, the tighter bond with the support, as well as the decreasing crystallite size [54,55]. Furthermore, their F2g (1) and A1g bands exhibit broader asymmetrical shapes, indicating asymmetric bending with oxygen with respect to the Co atoms and distortions of the spinel structure due to different environments occupied not only by cobalt ions but also by Mg cations from the washcoat [55–57]. Only very small shift was observed for the samples with SiO2 washcoat, while fully insignificant shifts were observed for the samples with the MnO2 and TiO2 washcoat, (device resolution is 4 cm−1). The crystallite sizes Lc of the Co3O4 phase deposited on the washcoats were lower in all cases compared to the reference sample but no relationship between L c and Raman shifts was observed (Tables 2 and 4), which means that the final shift for samples with the MgO and SiO2 washcoat is the combination of several effects. Furthermore, the bands at 377 and 414 cm−1 ascribed to corundum (Al2O3) were also identified [58]. For the Co-Cs/TiO2/Al2O3 catalyst, the band at 144 cm−1 confirmed the presence of anatase [59]. The results of TPR-H2 (Table 5 , Fig. 6 .) showed the effect of different washcoats on the Co3O4 reducibility. Unfortunately, the TPR measurements had to be terminated at 450 °C to avoid sublimation of Cs and the high-temperature region could not be monitored. Reduction of Co3O4 in the reference sample was manifested by one peak (T max2 = 379 °C) with low temperature shoulder (T max1 = 345 °C) belonging to reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and subsequently to Co [60, 61]. For the sample with TiO2 washcoat, T max1 shifted to higher temperature by 20 °C, while T max1 of other samples remained unchanged leading to the conclusion that reducibility of Co3+ became worse only in the case of the TiO2 washcoat. The second maximum (T max2) shifted to higher temperatures for all samples with the exception of Co-Cs/SiO2/AlO3, i.e. Co2+reducibility was worse due to interaction of cobalt with the washcoats, with the exception of SiO2. The strong cobalt-TiO2 interaction manifested itself by the shift of both TPR maxima to higher temperatures could be explained by the formation of surface titanate which is more resistant to reduction than Co3O4 [62, 63]. A similar impact of Mg on the reducibility of cobalt oxide was already mentioned in refs. [28,64–66]. Since Raman microspectroscopy proved only the effect of Mg- and SiO2-containing washcoats on Co3O4 structure, it is more probable that the hardly reducible phases containing titanium are created during TPR-H2 and were not present on the catalyst before reduction [67]. From all the tested washcoats, only MnO2 is reduced in the studied temperature range [10,64]. The corresponding reduction peak can be seen as a shoulder at 440 °C in the TPR profile of Co-Cs/MnO2/Al2O3. Comparison of the reducible species amount in the temperature range of 20–450 °C (expressed as mmol of H2 per g of active layer) showed that the catalysts with SiO2 and TiO2 washcoats contain the same reducible species loading as the reference sample, which confirmed that all cobalt species were reduced to Co0 up to 450 °C. No effect of the SiO2 washcoat on Co3O4 reducibility was observed similarly as in Refs. [60,67,68]. This fact can exclude the formation of cobalt silicate as a consequence of cobalt-SiO2 interactions that can lead to a worse reducibility of the catalyst [67]. In opposite, the worse reducibility of Co3O4 was observed due to the interaction with TiO2. The MnO2-washcoated catalyst possesses also the same amount of reducible species as the reference sample, although the detected H2 consumption is not related only to cobalt species, but also to MnO2 from the washcoat. In this case, reduction of the cobalt species in the high temperature region above 450 °C cannot be excluded. Similarly, the lower amount of reducible species in the temperature region up to 450 °C for the sample with MgO-n washcoat means that this catalyst also contains Co species that are not reduced in the low temperature region, i.e. hardly reducible species are formed via interaction with the washcoat material. In contrast, the Co-Cs/MgO-c/Al2O3 sample has even twice higher H2 consumption due to the interference of CO2 simultaneously released from carbonate residues (confirmed by quadrupole MS). That is why the number of reducible species in this sample is biased and cannot be used for comparison with other catalysts. The clear active phase-washcoat interactions for the catalysts with MgO are in accordance with the Raman microspectroscopy results. Furthermore, TPR analysis is sensitive to dispersion of Cs and Co in the catalysts, as the presence of Cs affects the reducibility of Co3O4 [9]. Since the results of XRD, Raman, and SEM confirm that the samples differ in crystallite sizes, cobalt oxide dispersion and that some of the cesium atoms are located on the catalyst surface without having any contact with the deposited cobalt oxide particles, some effect on the shape of the TPR profile cannot be excluded. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the synthesized catalysts All tested samples showed stable performance and no deactivation was observed during catalytic measurements (∼20 h). Studied cobalt based catalysts showed 100% selectivity to nitrogen according to literature [5] as was also confirmed in our earlier works by analysis of NO and also O2 and N2 [52,69]. The temperature dependence of N2O conversion (Fig. 7 a) showed that the highest N2O conversion was achieved over the sample containing MgO washcoat prepared from carbonates; the activity was comparable to the sample without any washcoat. The conversions on the catalysts with various types of washcoat decreased in order: Co-Cs/MgO-c/Al2O3 > Co-Cs/MgO-n/Al2O3 > Co-Cs/SiO2/Al2O3 = Co-Cs/TiO2/Al2O3 > Co-Cs/MnO2/Al2O3. Since each catalyst possessed a different amount of active phase, the comparison of rate constants related to the amount of active phase was done (Eq. (1)): (1) k = ln ( 1 1 − X N 2 O ) · V . w acti ve phase where, k is 1st order rate constant [70], X N 2 O is conversion of N2O, wactive phase is Co3O4 Cs weight and V ˙ is total volume flow (293 K, 101 325 Pa). The samples with washcoat had lower rate constants (Fig. 7b) than the uncoated sample despite a considerably higher surface area. The kinetic constants of the catalysts with washcoat decreased in the following order: Co-Cs/MgO-c/Al2O3 > Co-Cs/MgO-n/Al2O3 > Co-Cs/SiO2/Al2O3 = Co-Cs/TiO2/Al2O3 > Co-Cs/MnO2/Al2O3. 4 Discussion N2O decomposition is known to be redox in nature and depends on the electronic properties of the active sites [21]. The reaction starts by electron transfer from catalyst surface to N2O antibonding orbital accompanied by fast dissociation into N2 and adsorbed O − Eq. (2)) and continues by diffusion of surface oxygen intermediates and their recombination into O2 molecule (Eq. (3)) by Langmuir-Hinschelwood mechanism or reaction with N2O from gas phase by Eley-Rideal mechanism (Eq. (4)). It is known [21] that different electronic properties of cobalt spinel phase reflected in value of work function, that is closely connected with the cobalt oxygen bond strength and thus with the easiness of electron donation to N2O antibonding orbital (surface oxidation, Eq. (2)) and back to active site during oxygen desorption (surface reduction, Eqs. (3) and ((4)) [5]. (2) N 2 O + * → N 2 + O * (3) 2 O * ↔ O 2 + 2 * (4) N 2 O + O * → N 2 + O 2 + * The original aim of the experiment was the washcoat deposition to ensure higher surface area of the foam support and attainability of the active phase consisting of cesium-doped cobalt mixed oxide. This goal was fulfilled, however, catalytic results showed that catalytic activity did not follow the surface area trend, which means that the washcoat material also affected active sites properties. The XRD revealed that washcoated catalysts possess smaller Co3O4 crystallites than the reference sample, however, there is no dependence of the N2O conversion or kinetic constant on Lc . Another possible reason of different activity may be chemical interactions of the active phase with washcoats, which were observed by Raman microscopy and TPR-H2 especially for the MgO containing samples. We tried to see some correlation between reducibility expressed as temperature maxima, hydrogen consumption, or the onset of the temperature of reduction, i.e. Co3+ reduction, which is considered as the slowest step of N2O catalytic decomposition, however no clear dependence was obtained. The catalytic reaction is a surface process, which can explain why the results shown above are not relevant - they indicate bulk properties of the catalyst. It does not mean that they are useless, but we have to keep in mind that different bulk materials have different surface properties. Generally, the XPS results reflected surface changes and, in our case, showed that catalytic activity depended on the surface Cs/Co molar ratio (Fig. 8 ) and thus also on the surface Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio (Fig. 4). The most active sample is the sample with the highest abundance of Co3+ species. The observations are in accordance with results in [71], where it was suggested that deN2O activity of Co3O4 is influenced by Co3+/Co2+ratio and literature results [47] showing that active sites for N2O decomposition on Co3O4 are Co3+ ions in octahedral positions of the Co3O4 spinel matrix whereas the tetrahedral Co2+ ions were found to be much less active. Co3+ octahedral cobalt ions are easily accessible to reactants, facilitating the N2O chemisorption (Eq. (2)). Moreover, they are responsible for oxidation of superoxy species by accepting the released electron thus influencing desorption of dioxygen molecule, which is the rate determining step. The non-monotonous dependence of activity on the Cs/Co molar ratio Fig. 8) is caused by the formation of the surface dipoles after doping the surface with a small amount of cesium, thus favoring electron transfer from the surface to the N2O molecule (Eq. (2)) and from oxygen intermediates back to the surface (Eqs. (3), ((4)). On the other hand, a higher amount of Cs promoter causes depolarization of the dipoles and a reversible effect. This correlation was confirmed for the dependency of activity and work function on surface potassium loading [21]. The optimal doping range is very narrow and different for each specific catalytic system [22]. The different surface Cs/Co molar ratios can explain different activities; however, at first sight it seems strange to observe differences in the Co/Cs ratio, since the same ratio of Cs/Co was used for all of the catalysts during preparation. The explanation of how different Cs/Co ratio was created lies in catalyst morphology. XRD confirmed different sizes of Co3O4 crystallites. The SEM results showed that agglomeration of the Co3O4 primary particles occurred, while the Cs distribution was homogeneous. Moreover, if cesium sublimation occurred during calcination, the sublimation process [72] will differ according to the structure of the pores, from which the cesium vaporizes. XPS measures the chemical composition of the surface layer up to 10 nm thick, so if cobalt oxide forms bulky aggregates as well as small nanoparticles or thin layer, the Cs/Co molar ratio can be different at the surface nanometer level. Based on the N2O decomposition reaction mechanism, the optimal strength of the bond between the active site and adsorbed oxygen allowing easy repeated oxidation and reduction of the active site is decisive parameter, while the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ is considered as the slowest step. The bond strength can be influenced by the amount of Cs, while the dependence shows a relatively narrow optimum of 0.5–2 atoms Cs/nm2 [22]. However, the value was found for bulk catalysts and current work shows that it cannot be applied to open-cell catalysts with washcoat by setting the optimal Cs/Co ratio in the impregnation solution. The different washcoats had different surfaces, which together with the interactions between the active phase and the washcoat caused different dispersions of Cs and Co3O4, leading to different Cs/Co ratios on the surface of the catalysts even though the optimal Cs/Co ratio was set for all catalysts during synthesis. Because of this, there were changes in the strength of the Co-O bond, which was further influenced by the interactions between the active phase and the washcoat, which reflected in the change in the reducibility of the catalysts and, as a result, in the kinetic constants of N2O decomposition. In addition, the achieved N2O conversions were also influenced by the different chemical nature of the washcoats, which caused that their applied amounts varied. 4 Conclusions The structured catalysts containing Co3O4 modified with 1 wt.% of Cs as the active phase, deposited on α-Al2O3 open-cell ceramic foam coated with different oxide washcoats (MgO, MnO2, SiO2 and TiO2) were studied for the N2O decomposition. The washcoat was applied to increase the foam surface area and the chemical and structural suitability of the washcoat for the N2O decomposition was evaluated. All washcoats increased the surface area of the catalysts, some of them considerably, despite the fact that only TiO2 and MgO from carbonates covered the whole surface of the foam by continuous layer. Co3O4 deposited on the washcoat was unequal in the form of small nanoparticles and aggregates of different sizes consisting of crystallites of smaller size than on the sample without any washcoat. The cesium distribution was homogeneous. The MgO and MnO2 washcoats chemically interacted with the active Co3O4 phase, thus changing its reducibility. TiO2 influenced the reducibility only slightly, while no changes of reducibility were observed for the SiO2 washcoat. Catalytic activity did not reflect surface area values or reducibility properties, but correlated with the surface Cs/Co molar ratio closely interconnected with the surface Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio. The highest activity was achieved for the sample with the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio corresponding to optimal Cs/Co molar ratio around 0.1. Variations in the Cs/Co ratio were observed as a result of the different levels of aggregation of cobalt oxides and distribution of cesium species. Because of absence of chemical interactions, SiO2 is worth using as the washcoat; however, optimization of its deposition procedure in order to increase its amount on the catalyst is the next logical step. The optimization has to be done together with the optimization of the amount of Cs and the amount of the Co3O4 phase, since these parameters together affect the surface Cs/Co molar ratio and consequently electronic properties of cobalt cations responsible for the catalytic activity in the N2O decomposition. The significance of coating Al2O3 surface lies in the increase of the catalyst specific surface area and after optimization of SiO2 washcoat loading and Cs/Co molar ratio, the improvement of catalytic activity of resulted catalyst is expected. coredata.dc:description: The Co3O4 modified with 1 wt.% Cs was deposited on α-Al2O3 open-cell foam covered with different washcoats (MgO, MnO2, SiO2, TiO2), investigated by XRD, Raman microspectroscopy, nitrogen physisorption, XPS, SEM and TPR-H2 in order to elucidate interactions between Cs-Co3O4 and the washcoat and their effect on surface area, reducibility, dispersion, and low temperature decomposition of N2O. The samples with SiO2 and TiO2 washcoats had the largest surface areas. Only SiO2 did not interact with the active phase and did not change the reducibility of the catalyst. Although the same Cs concentration was adjusted during preparation of all catalysts, differences in the Cs/Co surface molar ratio were observed due to a different level of Co3O4 particles aggregation and cesium dispersion. Catalytic activity correlated with the surface Cs/Co molar ratio closely interconnected with the surface Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio while there were no direct relationships to the redox properties and surface area. The highest activity was achieved for the MgO washcoat prepared from carbonate with the highest Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio corresponding to the optimal Cs/Co surface molar ratio around 0.1.
coredata.dc:title: Washcoated open-cell foam cobalt spinel catalysts for N2O decomposition
